text: Now, I'd like to introduce our featured presenter today, Dr. Lucia Aronica.
Lucia is a lecturer at the Stanford Prevention Research Center and primary instructor of
the epigenomics and microbiomics module of the Stanford Genomics Certificate at the Stanford Center for Professional Development.
Lucia is currently leading the epigenetic analysis of the Stanford diet fits study by Professor Christopher Gardner.
The largest randomized clinical trial ever undertaken to compare low-carb versus low-fat diets,
for the design of personalized weight loss strategies. The focus of her research is investigating how diet affects the epigenome and
whether we can use epigenetic biomarkers to design personalized weight loss plans. Lucia also serves as an advisor for companies
active in the personal genomics and precision health field. Lucia received her PhD from
the University of Vienna and has research experience from the University of Oxford, University of Southern California,
and University Frederico, the second of Naples. She has published research papers in top ranked peer reviewed journals such as Cell,
Genes, and Development and the EMBO journal. And with that, let's turn it over to Lucia.
So thank you very much for having me here. It's a pleasure to, um, talk today, uh,
about unlocking your genetic potential using the science of epigenetics.
Um, and this is, uh, and why, uh, so my why my mission is using science to live a healthier happier life and,
uh, um, helping people, uh, um, achieving, uh, this. Um, you can follow us at EPIwellness and,
ah, find more information at draronica.com. Um, I do these through my research and teaching.
If my research could be a painting, it would be this painting here.
And not because the author Giuseppe Arcimboldo was Italian as I am.
[NOISE] The reason is that Giuseppe seemed to know that food shapes our biology and it
does so through two processes that are
the cornerstone of my research here at Stanford; nutrigenetics and nutrigenomics.
Nutrigenetics describes how genes can affect our response to diet,
whereas nutrigenomics describes how diet can affect our gene expression.
So this is like a give and take sort of conversation.
Um, and it's, uh, uh, and, uh, this is my main research interests here at Stanford.

tell me that they come out of my courses, uh, empowered to use science to improve their health.
And I hope that today, I can give you a taste of that and you can,
um, uh take home, um, uh, some messages, uh, actionable information to improve your health.
So today, we will learn, um, about [NOISE] what is epigenetics and how it is different from genetics.
How diet can impact our epigenetics and health and how epigenetics can help us take ownership on our health.

between epigenetics and genetics is especially important now,
uh, that, um, there are several companies, um, using genetic testing, uh,
to predict everything about us: what we should eat,
where, and even what kind of music, uh, should we listen to.
Uh, but, um- so all these companies work,

by using biological markers that are unique,um, for, um,
um- so they're really unique for people, um, personalized characteristics.
And these biomarkers are genomics, epigenomics, espo- exposomics.
So the entire set of environmental factors we are exposed to: metabolomics;
the metabolites in our body, proteomics; all the proteins, uh, in our cells and tissues,
and the microbiome; the universe of microbes, uh, within us and on us.

Um, uh, but we know that the other omics sciences,
they're called the lifestyle omics, are actually responsive to, uh,
what we do to our environment, our lifestyle and, um, uh, therefore are of particular interest in the field of,
uh, uh, preventative medicine and lifestyle medicine. And, uh, uh, they can also enhance
the predictive power of genomics markers when measured alone.
So why do we need to integrate genetic testing with lifestyle omics markers for precise health predictions?
Uh, let's have a genetic refresher to, um, in order to answer this question.
Um, our, uh, DNA is made of four uh, four building blocks for nucleotide, glunucleotides, uh,
ATGC that, uh, provide the information for, um, uh,
building the sequence of the amino acids in the proteins, uh, that build up our cells and tissues.
Uh, and, uh, uh, a multi-billion dollar, uh,
project running from, um, the '90s until, uh, 2003, the Human Genome Project,
aimed at sequencing the entire sequence of the human DNA.
So the human genome. Uh, and there was a lot of hope,
uh, behind these projects. Um, and, um, I was one of th- the- of the people,
uh, very excited about this project. Actually, I started my university studies in 2000 and these was one reason for me,
uh, to, um, uh, to, uh, decide to pursue, uh,
studies in molecular biology, uh, and genomics. And scientists were literally betting on
how many genes would turn up when the human genome will be finally mapped.
Um. And, uh, but the human genome as you may know produce some shocking surprises.
Uh, the first shocking surprise was, uh, that we, uh,
humans have, uh, um, uh, actually the same more or less the same number of genes, um,
as a simple model systems such as mice,
fruit flies, and worms and 50 times fewer than an onion.
The second shocking surprise was that genes account for only two percent of,
uh, our DNA, and if that, uh, weren't enough to hurt our genetic egos, uh,
there is a third shocking surprise, uh, um, that actually your DNA is 99.9 similar to any other person's DNA.
So, um, technically speaking, our DNA can explain only 0.1 percent of what make us unique.
And, um, therefore, it's perhaps not surprising,
um, [LAUGHTER] that also my, um, genetic report, um,
was not very accurate in predicting my, um, hair type.
So according to my genetic report, I'm 72 percent likely to have a straight hair.
Um, uh, and for the same reason, um, uh,
we were not surprised when we, uh,
receive the, um, uh, genomic results for our study, the DIETFITS study.
This is a, um, a study by Professor Christopher Gardner, um,
with 609 overweight and obese men and women that are randomized,
uh, to either low carb or low-fat diet that they follow for one year.
Uh, we are measuring, uh, um, genomics, genomics microbiomics, uh, proteomic,
uh, mark- markers for our study. And, uh, um, we published the results for,
um, for the genetic part, and we, uh,
actually cannot, um, uh, replicate some genetic associations that,
uh, uh, had been published, uh, previously, um, uh, associating, uh,
a three genes in the glucose and fat metabolism, uh, with the, um, uh, um,
prediction, um, um, of, uh, diet response either low carb or low fat.
Ah, and that's why we are now focusing on epigenetics and we are measuring the DNA methylation,
um, looking for epigenetic, uh, uh, biomarkers of diet response.
So what is epigenetics? You may remember, um, the, uh,
2008 cover of the Time Magazine stating, um, uh,
that the new science of epigenetics reveals how
the choices you make can change your genes and those of your kids.
Um, uh, so epigenetics, um, to, to understand epigenetics,
um, uh, let's just, um, describe the meaning of the word,
uh, that comes from the, uh, Greek language where epi means above, on the top.
So if your DNA is your genome, then your epigenome, uh,
is actually a set of molecular markers, uh, chemical groups that are on the top of your DNA and,
uh, can, uh, uh, switch genes on and off, just like a dimmer switch can modulate,
uh, lights up and down in a room. And this process of turning genes on and off can
explain why we have different types of cells in our body,
liver cells, neurons, fat cells, all told,
more than 200 types of cells, it all shares the same DNA, the same information.
So how is this possible? Well, think of, uh,
your DNA, your genome as, uh, uh, hardware.
Then, um, the epigenome is software that can, uh, uh,
uh, turn, uh, genes on and off, uh, specifically in different cells.
So yeah, the each cells, uh, each cell will turn off, uh,
turn a specific set of genes, um, and turn on only those genes that are required for,
uh, its identity and function. To understand the software,
we, uh, need to, uh, understand two fundamental properties of the epigenome;
epigenetic flexibility and memory. So unlike genetic sequence,
our genome is flexible, uh, and dynamically it responds to, um, lifestyle factors.
Um, and, uh, uh, this is [NOISE] uh, both, um,
this, um, uh, happens already very early in life.
So when, um, the egg and sperm fuse together,
actually they erase all or almost all the epigenetic marks giving rise to,
uh, embryonic stem cells. These stem cells can become any type of cell
because they don't have epigenetic markers to instruct the cell,
um, about which genes to turn on and off. But when during the, uh, embryo, uh,
fetal development, these cells do acquire epigenetic marks,
then they do start to di- differentiate in the different,
uh, types of cells that make up our mark- body. Uh, and as you can imagine, um,
uh, embryonic and fetal development are the- are, are time windows that are particularly sensitive to,
um, lifestyle factors and, uh, that's- this is the reason why,
um, pregnant women should be especially careful, o- o- of their lifestyle because these can have, uh,
huge impact on the epigenome of the developing, uh, fetus.
There are many lifestyle factors affecting the epigenome.
Um, diet, uh, pollutants, stress, drugs, chemicals, additives, um, and, uh, the,
the way these lifestyle factors can impact, um,
our epigenome and gene expression is by sending signals to enzymes, proteins,
that either write, erase or read epigenetic modifications on our genes,
thus effect- affecting, uh, gene expression.
The four you can think of the epigenome as a set of sticky notes placed on your genes.
That can store an epigenetic, uh, molecular memory that is called epigenetic memory of your lifestyle exposures.
The delicate balance between flexibility and
molecular stability is what makes it possible for our c-cells to store an epigenetic memory.
Epigenetic marks are flexibly, uh, modified by lifestyle factors,
but they're stable through cell division,
and can, uh, be therefore passed to the daughter cells.
And this makes, uh, epigenetic memory possible.
Now, the nodes, the markers that are
written before our birth tend to be written in pen,
so they tend to be permanent. Whereas the nodes that are taken after our birth are potentially reversible,
as if written with a pencil. And both pen and pencil marks can affect our,
er, um, health and presupposition, um, for, uh, diseases.
So, um, while, uh, genetic, uh, um,
factors can, uh, contribute, uh, to, uh, our traits to a process of hard-wiring.
Uh, epigenetic markers, uh, do so by a process of soft-wiring that is, um,
dynamically, uh, influenced by our environment and lifestyle.
And that's why, uh, for example identical twins, uh, that have exactly the same DNA, um,
can, um, with time not only look different,
but also, uh, develop, uh, different, uh, presupposition to disease.
Now, there, uh, have been a thousand studies on the impact of,
uh, diet of, um, on our epigenetics. Um, and actually epigenetics,
um, is an opportunity, uh, for us, uh, to look at diet from a new perspective.
Uh, food, uh, is not only calories, it's information,
is the most potent signal, powerful signals to our genes.
Um, uh, and it can actually modulate several of those enzymes that can write,
erase, and read epigenetic, uh, modifications.
One of the- the most famous studies in animal, uh,
around diet and epigenome is a study, uh, coming from a beehive.
So, um, queen bees are much larger,
uh, than other bees, uh, in a beehive that are called, uh, worker bees.
They also live longer, and they are faster. They can lay eggs whereas worker bees cannot.
Now, what is surprising is that
queen bees and worker bees are genetically identical.
And what is even more surprising, is that the only difference is that only queen bees are fed royal jelly.
A protein-rich substance that is actually secreted by worker bees,
and this tells a lot about fairness in nature. Um, and, uh, that can actually turn on
specific genes that make the queen become a queen.
But before you run to your local store and buy royal jelly,
I have to tell you that this don't seem to work for, uh, humans. Uh, we do have,
um, uh, nutrients, uh, that, uh, we know are through an epigenetic, uh, mechanism,
and we are discovering every day, uh, new, uh, nutrients in this, uh, category.
Uh, I call these nutrients EPI-nutrients. Uh, these are our royal jelly.
Uh, uh, they, uh, nourish our epigenome and unlock our full potential.

nutrients that can actually provide the building blocks for making,
uh, the switches, the epigenetic switches. These include methionine, folate,
vitamin B12, B6, choline, betaine. Uh, and the nutrients on the right,
uh, this one in- in violet, they can actually, um,
modulate the, uh, er, activity of those writers and erasers and readers,
um, and, uh, so affect, uh, our epigenome. Uh, these include, uh,
many polyphenols such as for example, those from green tea, uh, resveratrol, from red wine, um,
some, um, flavonoids in soy, uh, genistein, sulforaphane,
a very famous EPI-nutrient, uh, found in all cruciferous vegetables and broccoli.
Butyrate, a very interesting, uh, nutrient that is actually produced, uh,
in the gut when dietary fiber is fermented. Um, and so it's also heavily dependent on our microbiome, uh,
and then, uh, diallyl sulfide or that's from, uh, uh, garlic.
So all of these studies are showing that we are, uh, what we eat.

our, what our parents and grandparents ate. Um, one of these studies, uh,
is, uh, again, an animal study. Um, ah, and these two mice here are very fence.

AVY that genetically programs these mice to become fat,
um, develop yellow fur and develop, um, ah, late, ah, later in life diabetes.
But the AVY gene is turned on
only in the yellow fat mouse, Why?
Uh, actually because of the diet of,
uh, um, the mother of these mice. So, um, for the yellow mouse, um,
the matter of the yellow mouse had a diet that was poor enough nutrients.
And, uh, for these reasons, um, her daughter couldn't, um, build, the building,
the building blocks of the epigenome and turn off the AVY allele during
em- embryonic development whereas the mother of the allele brown mouse was behaving well and eating,

And as a result, um, her daughter could turn off the AVY gene.

Well, there is evidence not from an experiment but from, um, a historic tragedy.
Um, ah, this was the Dutch Hunger Winter during World War II.
There was, ah, a food embargo in Holland and as a result,
uh, more than 20,000 people died. Um, ah, as you can, uh, imagine the,
the mothers- the babies born during the famine were underweight and,
ah, had a lot of health issues, uh, and this is not surprising. But what is surprising is that when these babies, um, became adults,

And, uh, what is even more surprising is that, ah,
the children of the famine babies had also a higher risk of becoming obese

glucose metabolism and fat metabolism, uh, which suggests that there was, um,
there were some epigenetic marks written in pen, uh, during the famine that that, uh, uh, persisted,
um, later in life and, uh, had long-term consequences of- on the metabolic health of people.

also the diet of fathers. And these are a recent study, um,

in the sperm cells of, uh, obese people are dramatically different from, um,
uh those found in lean people and, um, [NOISE] they are found in, uh,
genes that regulate brain function and appetite, uh,

the problem with obesity, um, uh, and the metabolic disease.
